abstract.p: Letter from Thomas W Shreve (Kim Eng Securities) says Thomas L Friedman is off the mark in predicting future of Indonesia based on Suharto era (Oct 3 Op-Ed column)

block.p: Re ''What a Mess!'', by Thomas L. Friedman (column, Oct. 3):

Those of us who have lived in Indonesia in the final years of the Suharto era and its first two years of transition to democracy can sympathize with Mr. Friedman's frustration. But his comparison of Indonesia to Russia (and, as an apparent afterthought, Pakistan) is considerably wide of the mark.
Re ''What a Mess!'', by Thomas L. Friedman (column, Oct. 3):

Those of us who have lived in Indonesia in the final years of the Suharto era and its first two years of transition to democracy can sympathize with Mr. Friedman's frustration. But his comparison of Indonesia to Russia (and, as an apparent afterthought, Pakistan) is considerably wide of the mark.

Ask any Indonesian if the country ''works,'' and you will no doubt hear a litany of complaints. But these complaints do not include that systems and structures affecting them on a daily basis have broken down, or that the next turn in Indonesian policy cannot be derived from the psychological analysis of a single individual.

It is not considered a weakness in the United States that policy cannot be predicted from the personality of Bill Clinton. That is called decentralization of power, and on balance, Indonesians like it.
THOMAS W. SHREVE Director of Corporate Finance Kim Eng Securities Jakarta, Indonesia, Oct. 3, 2000
